text:
RAHMI KOC: We also
think long term

because we don't have
to account every quarter

on the value of our shares at
the [INAUDIBLE] stock exchange.

So in America, this gives
the pressure on management

to always have to come up with
better figures each quarter.

Or if you underperform, then
your share price is affected.
We look at long term.

Secondly, only 21% of our
shares, of controlling shares,
are traded.

And 81% of that is
foreign investors.

And the rest, 70% is
the family and 10%

is the foundation,
Vehbi Koc Foundation.

So if you own 70%
of the business,

no matter how capable an army
of professional management

you have, you still have
to keep a very close eye
how things are going.

For example, as long
as they perform well

and do their budgets, we
don't interfere at all.

Until such time that there
is an unforeseen investment

or something that's not
within their budget.

Then we have a committee
that comes to the committee.

The committee
decides what to do.

Otherwise, we don't get involved
in day-to-day business at all.

And another interesting
thing is that we
learned from foreign advisors.

In the past, if my
father had called

into how to institutionalize
the business more,

they said, no family member
should be directly involved

in the business because they
are not the same qualifications.
They're not the same brightness.
They're not the same capability.

And you cannot dismiss a family
member if they perform badly.

Whereas a professional, you can
always say and shake his hand
and your job is finished.

The reverse is that if
the professional messes

up the business, causes
you a lot of damage

and just takes his hat
and goes, and you're

left with all the
mess to clear out,

all the losses and all the
loss of prestige and so on.

Therefore, we have to be,
although behind the scenes,

very closely involved
in what's going on.
